Accounting policies Notes to the Company

policies Notes to the Company financial statements

Basis of preparation 1. Intangible assets of preparation 1. Intangible assets – goodwill The financial statements are presented in sterling, rounded to the nearest million. They are prepared under the historical cost convention, except that derivative cost cost instruments At 13 September financial instruments are stated at their fair value, and in accordance with applicable United Kingdom accounting standards (UK GAAP) and the Companies Act 2006. At 13 September 2008 and 12 September 2009

of preparation 1. Intangible assets – goodwill

As permitted by s408(4) of the Companies Act 2006, a separate profit and loss account for the Company has not been included in these financial statements. amortisation amortisation by FRS 1, At 13 September 2008 As permitted by FRS 1, no cash flow statement for the Company has been included on the grounds that the group includes the Company in its own published At 13 September 2008

The Company has taken advantage of the exemption in FRS 25 – , not to prepare a note to the financial statements Financial Instruments: Disclosure and Presentation

Intangible assets – goodwill net book value at 12 september Intangible assets consist of goodwill arising on acquisitions since 17 September 1998, being the excess of the fair value of the purchase consideration of businesses over the fair value of net assets acquired. Goodwill is capitalised in accordance with FRS 10 and amortised over its useful life, not exceeding 20 years. Goodwill previously written off against reserves has not been reinstated. 2. Investments in subsidiaries

Investments in subsidiaries At 13 September 2008 Investments in subsidiaries are reported at cost less any provision for impairment. Additions

Financial instruments at 12 september All financial assets and financial liabilities are measured initially at fair value, plus directly attributable transaction costs, and thereafter at amortised cost.

Pensions and other post-employment benefits The additions relate to an increase in the investment The additions relate to an increase in the investment of the Company’s wholly owned subsidiary, ABF Investments plc, and the allocation of shares under the The Company operates defined contribution and defined benefit pension schemes. Contributions to the defined contribution scheme are charged to the profit and loss Share Incentive Plan to employees of the Company’s subsidiaries. Share Incentive Plan to employees of the Company’s subsidiaries. account as they become payable. The principal defined benefit scheme is a multi-employer scheme and the Company is unable to identify its share of underlying assets There were no provisions for impairment in either year. There were no provisions for impairment in either year. liabilities on a consistent and reasonable basis. Hence, and liabilities on a consistent and reasonable basis. Hence, contributions to this scheme are accounted for as if they were contributions to a defined contribution scheme. The Company has one small unfunded defined benefit scheme which it accounts for in accordance with FRS 17 using the advice of professional actuaries. The amount charged to the profit and loss account is the cost of benefits accruing to employees over the year, plus any benefit improvements granted to members during the year. 3. Debtors 3. Debtors It also includes a charge equal to the expected interest on plan liabilities over the year. The present value of plan liabilities is disclosed as a liability on the balance sheet £m net of any related deferred tax. amounts falling due

The additions relate to an increase in the investment of the Company’s wholly owned subsidiary, ABF Investments plc, and the allocation of shares under the

There were no provisions for impairment in either year. liabilities on a consistent and reasonable basis. Hence,

3. Debtors

Share-based payments Amounts owed by subsidiaries The Share Incentive Plan allows employees of the Company to receive allocations of shares to be distributed subject to attainment of certain financial performance Other debtors 3 criteria and typically after a three-year performance period. The fair value of the shares to be awarded is recognised as an employee expense with a corresponding 45 increase in reserves. The fair value is measured at grant date and spread over the period during which the executives become unconditionally entitled to the shares. 2,478 The fair value of the shares allocated is measured taking into account the terms and conditions under which the shares were allocated. The amount recognised as amounts falling due after one year amounts falling due after one year is adjusted to reflect the actual number Amounts owed by subsidiaries an expense is adjusted to reflect the actual number of shares that vest. Amounts owed by subsidiaries

Where the Company grants allocations of shares to employees of its subsidiaries, these are accounted for on the same basis as for allocations to employees of the 1,432

The Share Option Scheme (1994) and Executive Share Option Scheme (2000) allow executives to acquire shares of the Company. The fair value of options granted The amount owed by joint ventures comprises a loan and accrued interest owed by Vivergo Fuels Limited. The amount owed by joint ventures comprises a loan and accrued interest owed by Vivergo Fuels Limited. as an employee expense with a corresponding increase in reserves. The fair value is measured at is recognised as an employee expense with a corresponding increase in reserves. The fair value is measured at grant date and spread over the period during which the executives become unconditionally entitled to the options. The fair value of the options granted is measured using a binomial lattice model, taking into account the terms The directors consider that the carrying amount of debtors approximates their fair value. The directors consider that the carrying amount of debtors approximates their fair value. and conditions upon which the options were granted. The amount recognised as an expense is adjusted to reflect the actual number of share options that vest except

The amount owed by joint ventures comprises a loan and accrued interest owed by Vivergo Fuels Limited. as an employee expense with a corresponding increase in reserves. The fair value is measured at

The directors consider that the carrying amount of debtors approximates their fair value.

4. Other creditors

Shares in the Company are held in a separate trust and are shown at cost as a deduction in arriving at equity shareholders’ funds.

The Company has provided £283m of guarantees in the ordinary course of business as at 12 September 2009 (2008 – £nil). These relate primarily to insurance payment obligations, the deferred consideration received described in note 5, and the fulfilment of obligations to the Rural Payments Agency in respect of income received by a subsidiary under the Sugar Restructuring Aid Scheme. On 30 September 2002 the Scheme was closed to new members, with defined contribution arrangements introduced for these members. For the defined contribution

The last actuarial valuation of the Associated British Foods Pension Scheme was carried out as at 5 April 2008. At the valuation date the total market value of the assets to allocation under the Associated British Foods plc Executive Share Incentive Plan 2003, are held in a separate trust. The trust is funded by the Company. of the Scheme was £2,223m and represented 93% of the benefits that had accrued to members after allowing for expected future increases in earnings. Following September 2009, the trust held 3,906,757 (2008 – 2,102,133) ordinary shares of the Company. The market value of these shares at the year end was completion of the actuarial valuation, the Company agreed to make five annual payments of £30m in order to eliminate the deficit at 5 April 2008. The first of these (2008 – £17m). The trust has waived its right to dividends. Refer to note 23 of the consolidated financial statements for further information on the group

Print

This paper is made from pre and post consumer waste and virgin wood fibre, independently certified in accordance with the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC). It is manufactured at a mill that is certified to ISO 14001 environmental management standards. The pulp is bleached using an elemental chlorine free
